articles.headline: Thomas Staggs, Disney’s Heir Apparent, Is Stepping Down
articles.snippet: Mr. Staggs, the chief operating officer, will leave next month, handing Disney a distracting succession search for a chief-in-waiting.
articles.abstract: Mr. Staggs, the chief operating officer, will leave next month, handing Disney a distracting succession search for a chief-in-waiting.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Thomas O. Staggs, the favored contender to lead Disney after Robert A. Iger’s retirement, unexpectedly announced his departure on Monday, throwing succession at the world’s largest entertainment company into disarray.

articles.headline: Despite Fears, Affordable Care Act Has Not Uprooted Employer Coverage
articles.snippet: Employer-based insurance has held firm for the last five years, and federal officials predict it will continue to remain strong.
articles.abstract: Employer-based insurance has held firm for the last five years, and federal officials predict it will continue to remain strong.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Affordable Care Act was aimed mainly at giving people better options for buying health insurance on their own. There were widespread predictions that employers would leap at the chance to drop coverage and send workers to fend for themselves.

articles.headline: Ted Cruz Is Fuming Because John Kasich Won’t Bow Out
articles.snippet: As Senator Ted Cruz looks beyond Wisconsin, where he is favored to win on Tuesday, his frustrations with the Ohio governor have increasingly been laid bare.
articles.abstract: As Senator Ted Cruz looks beyond Wisconsin, where he is favored to win on Tuesday, his frustrations with the Ohio governor have increasingly been laid bare.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, eyeing a victory here that could reshape the race for the Republican presidential nomination, has appeared most vexed by a rival he views as more of a long-term nuisance than a short-term threat: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: With a Stand-Alone App, Starz Looks Beyond the Cable Bundle
articles.snippet: Starz is the latest premium TV network to introduce an app that bypasses cable packages and lets viewers stream television shows and movies directly.
articles.abstract: Starz is the latest premium TV network to introduce an app that bypasses cable packages and lets viewers stream television shows and movies directly.

articles.headline: German Economy, Once Europe’s Leader, Now Looks Like Laggard
articles.snippet: Germany prospered in recent years by exporting to emerging countries. Now the slowdown in emerging markets is leaving Germany, and Europe, vulnerable.
articles.abstract: Germany prospered in recent years by exporting to emerging countries. Now the slowdown in emerging markets is leaving Germany, and Europe, vulnerable.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — China is cutting back on mining machinery as its economy slips. The United Arab Emirates and other Middle Eastern countries are no longer awash in oil money, putting luxury car brands at risk. Russia, still facing Western sanctions, cannot buy as much high-tech energy equipment.

articles.headline: Rejected by Colleges, SAT and ACT Gain High School Acceptance
articles.snippet: Both testing companies have pushed into the market for federally required tests in public schools, offering them even to students who do not plan to go to college.
articles.abstract: Both testing companies have pushed into the market for federally required tests in public schools, offering them even to students who do not plan to go to college.
articles.lead_paragraph: The SAT and the ACT, bugaboos of generations of college applicants, were supposed to shrink in significance as more colleges and universities moved away from requiring standardized test scores for admission.

articles.headline: Digital Paper in China Covers Contentious Issues, Now in English
articles.snippet: The Paper, a digital success in China, introduces an English-language version as the country’s leaders set conflicting goals for its news outlets.
articles.abstract: The Paper, a digital success in China, introduces an English-language version as the country’s leaders set conflicting goals for its news outlets.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The Paper is a new media success story in a fast-changing marketplace for news. It covers contentious issues — such as official corruption and a recent scandal involving improperly stored vaccines — with a clutch of digital bells and whistles. Its smartphone app, it says, has been downloaded about 10 million times.
